description: Number of anagrams of n that are primes.
comments: An anagram of a k-digit number is one of the k! permutations of the digits that does not begin with 0.
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: 107 has 2 prime anagrams: 107 and 701 (but not 017 or 071); so a(107) = 2.
prog: (Haskell)import Data.List (permutations, nub)a046810 n = length $ filter ((== 1) . a010051)                   $ map read (nub $ filter ((> '0') . head)                                            $ permutations $ show n)-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 14 2011
author: _David W. Wilson_
